meta.content: This paper presents the design for a high-speed permanent magnet synchronous machine (PMSMs) considering the demagnetization and mechanical characteristics of rare-earth magnets based on the operat...

This paper presents the design for a high-speed permanent magnet synchronous machine (PMSMs) considering the demagnetization and mechanical characteristics of rare-earth magnets based on the operat...
meta.name: twitter:description

meta.content: This paper presents the design for a high-speed permanent magnet synchronous machine (PMSMs) considering the demagnetization and mechanical characteristics of rare-earth magnets based on the operating temperature. The TRV equation and plane stress analytical method are considered for the temperature, the rotor size is derived from the analysis results of the sleeve thickness, and the stator is designed on the basis of the results of the electromagnetic analysis method. The B–H curve of the permanent magnet (PM) changes with its operating temperature; thus, a thermal demagnetization analysis is conducted to verify the irreversible demagnetization caused by the operating temperature and armature reaction field using electromagnetic finite element method (FEM). It is necessary to consider the irreversible demagnetization with the operating temperature because it can decrease the electromagnetic performance. Therefore, the electromagnetic characteristics of high-speed machines using rare-earth PMs are analyzed to confirm irreversible demagnetization. The validity of the proposed design is confirmed via comparative verifications with the measured results from prototype models.
meta.name: citation_abstract

head.title: Design of high-speed permanent magnet synchronous machines considering thermal demagnetization and mechanical characteristic of permanent magnet: AIP Advances: Vol 11, No 2

li.a: 65th Annual Conference on Magnetism and Magnetic Materials

div.div: This paper presents the design for a high-speed permanent magnet synchronous machine (PMSMs) considering the demagnetization and mechanical characteristics of rare-earth magnets based on the operating temperature. The TRV equation and plane stress analytical method are considered for the temperature, the rotor size is derived from the analysis results of the sleeve thickness, and the stator is designed on the basis of the results of the electromagnetic analysis method. The B–H curve of the permanent magnet (PM) changes with its operating temperature; thus, a thermal demagnetization analysis is conducted to verify the irreversible demagnetization caused by the operating temperature and armature reaction field using electromagnetic finite element method (FEM). It is necessary to consider the irreversible demagnetization with the operating temperature because it can decrease the electromagnetic performance. Therefore, the electromagnetic characteristics of high-speed machines using rare-earth PMs are analyzed to confirm irreversible demagnetization. The validity of the proposed design is confirmed via comparative verifications with the measured results from prototype models.
I. INTRODUCTION
Section:

select.name: select23
select.option: II. THE DESIGN OF THE ROT...

div.div:
The rapid development of manufacturing technologies for permanent magnets (PMs) in recent times has dramatically improved the efficiency and output power of PM synchronous machines (PMSMs); this has prompted the use of direct-drive-type high-speed PMSMs instead of the conventional mechanical gear transmission systems in various industrial fields. However, the rotor of the PMSM is known to often break during high-speed operations. Therefore, the durability and output characteristics of the machine must be improved for industrial applications.
1–7
1. Z. Huang and J. Fang, “
Multiphysics design and optimization of high-speed permanent magnet electrical machines for air blower applications
,” IEEE Trans. Ind. Electro.
63
, 2766 (2016).
https://doi.org/10.1109/TIE.2016.2518121
2. A. Damiano, A. Floris, G. Fois, I. Marongiu, M. Porru, and A. Serpi, “
Design of a high-speed ferrite-based brushless DC machine for electric vehicles
,” IEEE Trans. Ind. Appl.
53
, 4279 (2017).
https://doi.org/10.1109/TIA.2017.2699164
3. J. Dong, Y. Huang, L. Jin, and H. Lin, “
Comparative study of surface-mounted and interior permanent-magnet motors for high-speed applications
,” IEEE Trans., Appl. Supercond.
26
, 5200304 (2016).
https://doi.org/10.1109/TASC.2016.2514342
4. S. Musuroi, C. Sorandaru, M. Greconici, V. N. Olarescu, and M. Weinman, “
Low-cost ferrite permanent magnet assisted synchronous reluctance rotor an alternative for rare earth permanent synchronous motors
,” in
Industrial Electronics Society, IECON 2013—39th Annual Conference of the IEEE
(
IEEE
, 2013).
https://doi.org/10.1109/IECON.2013.6699602
5. K.-H. Kim, H.-I. Park, S.-M. Jang, D.-J. You, and J.-Y. Choi, “
Comparative study of electromagnetic performance of high-speed synchronous motors with rare-earth and ferrite permanent magnets
,” IEEE Trans. Magn.
52
, 8203404 (2016).
https://doi.org/10.1109/TMAG.2016.2532901
6. J.-H. Ahn, J.-Y. Choi, C. H. Park, C. Han, C.-W. Kim, and T.-G. Yoon, “
Correlation between rotor vibration and mechanical stress in ultra-high-speed permanent magnet synchronous motors
,” IEEE Trans. Magn.
53
, 8209906 (2017).
https://doi.org/10.1109/TMAG.2017.2710208
7. J. F. Gieras, C. Wang, and J. C. Lai,
Noise of Poly-phase Electric Motors
(
Taylor & Francis
,
New York, NY
, 2006).
Design methods for the rotor structures of high-speed PMSMs have thus been actively studied. Hong studied the rotor design considering rotor dynamics;
8
8. D.-K. Hong, B.-C. Woo, and D. H. Koo, “
Rotordynamics of 120,000 r/min 15kW ultra high speed motor
,” IEEE Trans. on Magn.
45
, 2831 (2009).
https://doi.org/10.1109/ICEF.2012.6310388
Ede considered the natural frequency and bending mode of the rotor;
9
9. J. D. Ede, Z. Q. Zhu, and D. Howe, “
Rotor resonances of high-speed permanent-magnet brushless machines
,” IEEE Trans on Ind. Appl.
38
, 1542 (2002).
https://doi.org/10.1109/TIA.2002.804765
Ahn designed a rotor structure considering a PM and determined the sleeve material stress analytically;
10
10. J.-h. Ahn, C. Han, C.-w. Kim, and J.-y. Choi, “
Rotor design of high-speed permanent magnet synchronous motors considering rotor magnet and sleeve materials
,” IEEE Trans. Appl. Superconduct.
28
, 5201504 (2018).
https://doi.org/10.1109/TASC.2017.2786690
Kim optimized the torque characteristics using the finite element method (FEM) by considering partial demagnetization;
11
11. K.-C. Kim, S.-B. Lim, D.-H. Koo, and J. Lee, “
The shape design of permanent magnet for permanent magnet synchronous motor considering partial demagnetization
,” IEEE Trans. Magn.
42
, 3485 (2006).
https://doi.org/10.1109/TMAG.2006.879077
Jeong considered irreversible demagnetization as a criterion to design the hybrid-type PMSM to optimize rotor shape with cost-effective aspects and output characteristics;
12
12. C.-L. Jeong and J. Hur, “
Optimization design of PMSM with hybrid-type permanent magnet considering irreversible demagnetization
,” IEEE Trans. Magn.
53
, 8110904 (2017).
https://doi.org/10.1109/TMAG.2017.2707102
Park designed the rotor structure of an interior permanent magnet synchronous motor (IPMSM) based on the irreversible characteristics of the PM along with its structural analysis.
13
13. M.-R. Park, H.-J. Kim, Y.-Y. Choi, J.-P. Hong, and J.-J. Lee, “
Characteristics of IPMSM according to rotor design considering nonlinearity of permanent magnet
,” IEEE Trans. Magn.
52
, 8101904 (2016).
https://doi.org/10.1109/TMAG.2015.2482987
However, these studies did not consider the changes in the characteristics of the rotor structure based on the operating temperatures. Thus, in this study, a simplified analytical model was developed and applied to prevent rotor breakage and to derive the mechanical stress for the rotor structure design by considering the temperature conditions. In particular, when designing the rotor structure of the high-speed PMSM, a protective tube is added to prevent breakage during high-speed rotation; generally, it is manufactured through shrink fitting. Based on the operating temperature, the stress characteristics generated by shrink fitting would change according to the thermal expansion characteristics of the materials. When the yield stress of the material exceeds permissible limits, the rotor structure is deformed or broken. In addition, the electromagnetic properties generally change according to the B–H characteristic curves based on the operating temperature, thereby causing irreversible magnetization during operation; this not only decreases the output but also alters the electromagnetic characteristics. Thus, the thermal characteristics of the materials used to fabricate the rotor need to be considered.
II. THE DESIGN OF THE ROTOR CONSIDERING THE MECHANICAL AND THERMAL CHARACTERISTIC DEPENDING ON MATERIALS
Section:

select.name: select23
select.option: II. THE DESIGN OF THE ROT... <<

div.div: A. Torque per unit rotor volume (TRV)

To derive the rotor size for a high-speed PMSM, one of the typical methods is to employ the equation for the torque per unit rotor volume (TRV), which is related to the electromagnetic performance of the machine. The TRV equation is set based on the expertise of the designer; in a previous study, the rotor size of the machine was selected using the TRV range for each type.
14
14. J. R. Hendershot Jt and T. J. E. Miler,
Design of Brushless Permanent-Magnet Motors
(
Magna Physics publising and Clarendon press-OXPORD
, 1994).
The equation of the TRV is given as
T
R

Where Dro is the diameter of the rotor and Lstk is axial length of machines. Through the TRV, an outer diameter of 26 mm and a length of 80 mm in the axial direction were selected.
B. Sleeve

To obtain the detailed design of the rotor, the stress is analyzed using a method based on the material characteristics and operating temperatures. To manufacture and operate a high-speed PMSM safely, the mechanical stress characteristics of the rotor must be analyzed for the operating temperature range by applying plane stress equation shrinkage fitting and varying the PM and sleeve diameter. Mechanically, if the stresses of the PM and sleeve are not considered in the design, the yield stresses of the materials may be exceeded, which might cause distortion and bending of the machines. Therefore, it is important to select a suitable PM and sleeve size for safe operation at the typical operating temperature, so that the ranges for the design variables can be determined. Further, it is necessary that the plane stress be derived using a simplified analytical method.

Table I
summarizes the mechanical parameters of some common rotor materials.

TABLE I.
Mechanical parameter of rotor materials.

Fig. 1
shows the design variable ranges derived using the von Mises stress analysis results by considering the temperature conditions according to the sleeve materials; the design range of Inconel is 0–98 µm, Ti-alloy is 0–150 µm, and SUS is 28–68 µm. The carbon fiber material does not have a design range; thus, carbon fibers are eliminated at the design stage. The differences in the results indicate that carbon fibers cannot be designed.
Fig. 2
shows the von Mises stress analysis according to the interference and rotor radius; in general, to have a sufficient stress margin for the rotor that increases according to the mode shape during rotation, the design uses a safety factor of more than 2. As a result, Inconel and Ti, which have higher safety factors than SUS materials, were selected for the study.

FIG. 1.
Von Mises stress analysis results on the sleeve according to the material: (a) Inconel, (b) Ti alloy, (c) SUS, (d) carbon fiber.

FIG. 2.
Von-Mises stress analysis results on PM.
C. The analysis of mode shape and natural frequency

The vibrations caused by electromagnetic excitation sources may exist within the resonance frequency band and can damage the machines. Hence, it is important to analyze the structural properties of these machines, i.e., natural frequencies and mode shapes. In addition, synchronous lateral vibrations of the rotating body are an important source of mechanical defects and are the most common problem with respect to vibration of the machines. Therefore, in the analysis, the focus was limited to lateral vibrations. The natural frequency and mode shape were analyzed through FEM.
Figs. 3(a)
and
(b)
show the Campbell diagram according to the material via mode analysis. Because the critical speed of the Ti-alloy model is within the operational range, it is considered that the design is impossible; however, the Inconel model can be designed because its critical speed exists outside the operational range. The contact point of each line is the point where each of the modes resonate.
Fig. 3(c)
shows the mode shape and natural frequency of the designed rotor. The first mode frequencies of the models are 1935 Hz and 3431 Hz.

FIG. 3.
Analysis results for mode shape and natural frequency according to the material: (a) Inconel Campbell diagram, (b) Ti-alloy Campbell diagram; (c) mode shape and natural frequency for Inconel.
D. The analysis of irreversible PM demagnetization

The increase in the temperature of the machine affects the performance of the PM coercive force, which decreases the subsequent performance of the machine. Thus, based on the temperature conditions of the system, it is necessary to perform irreversible demagnetization. Moreover, to design the parameters of the PMSM, the stator shape was designed based on the results of the magnetic flux density distribution analysis using FEM with nonlinear material data. Thus, analysis of the irreversible demagnetization is required. The diameter of the coil and number of turns of the phase were selected by considering the current density, space factor, and input voltage conditions. The detailed design specifications are summarized in
Table II
.

TABLE II.
Design specification of High-speed PMSM.

Fig. 4(a)
shows the demagnetization characteristics of the permanent magnet made of SmCo. When the temperature rises from room temperature (i.e., 20 °C) to 150 °C, the residual magnetic flux density and coercivity decrease, temporary demagnetization occurs, and operating point is shifted from A to B. Thus, the characteristics of the permanent magnet change depending on the temperature, and the design must be revised in consideration of this change. In this work, the irreversible demagnetization characteristics were analyzed at a rated operating temperature of 150 °C; the input current was 10 times the rated input current.
Fig. 4(b)
shows the characteristic analysis results of the PM irreversible demagnetization under the given set operating temperature conditions. Based on the obtained results, the machine can be operated at a temperature of 150 °C.

FIG. 4.
The analysis model and analysis results of PM irreversible demagnetization curve considering temperature conditions: (a) analysis model and flux density distribution (b) analysis results of PM irreversible demagnetization curve.
III. EXPERIMENTAL RESULTS
Section:

select.name: select23
select.option: II. THE DESIGN OF THE ROT...

div.div:
To validate the design results and the proposed method, the back-electromotive force (EMF) measurements and temperature saturation experiments were performed to confirm the operation of the fabricated machine using the proposed method without reduction of the output power and with breakage under the continuous operating temperature condition of 150 °C. The prototype machine was driven via pulse width modulation (PWM) control, and the operating speed during the temperature saturation experiment was maintained at values higher than 26500 rpm.
Fig. 5(a)
shows the prototype model. The stator assembly is manufactured with a thermocouple, and the rotor assembly is manufactured with an air-blow fan.
Figs. 5(b)
and
(c)
show the experimental results of temperature saturation, comparison of the analysis results, and line-to-line back-EMF. The results of the temperature saturation experiment confirm that the temperature condition caused by the ambient temperature and rated operation was 150 °C. The analysis results of the back-EMF at 9300 rpm was compared with those of the experiments. During operation of the machine, the rotor did not break, and the line-to-line voltage comparison showed good agreement. Moreover, it was confirmed that the required output power and efficiency characteristics were satisfied at the given operating temperature.

FIG. 5.
Prototype model of the high-speed PMSM, experimental and analysis results for temperature saturation, and comparison of the analysis results for line-to-line back-EMF: (a) Prototype model (b) temperature (c) line-to-line back-EMF.
IV. CONCLUSION
Section:

select.name: select23
select.option: II. THE DESIGN OF THE ROT...

div.div: In this study, a high-speed PMSM with 25,000 rpm and 60 kW capacity was designed using a rare-earth PM via mechanical and electromagnetic analyses and irreversible demagnetization analysis under high-temperature conditions. The sleeve material was selected by comparing the results of the stress analysis by FEM and given temperature condition. The irreversible demagnetization analysis confirmed that demagnetization did not occur at the rated operating temperature. For the rated load conditions, the measured results of the machine are in agreement with the designed results. In addition, it was confirmed through experiments that the machine operates without damage and output reduction. Thus, we expect that this analytical method can be applied to the design of high-speed PMSMs under various temperature conditions.
DATA AVAILABILITY
Section:

select.name: select23
select.option: II. THE DESIGN OF THE ROT...

div.div: The data that support the findings of this study are available from the corresponding author upon reasonable request.

This research was supported by the Basic Science Research Program through the National Research Foundation of Korea (NRF-2020R1A4A2002021); this work was supported by the National Research Foundation of Korea(NRF) grant funded by the Korea government(MSIT). (No. 2020R1A2C1007353)
